Dear Mr. Scheuer:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
November 4-November 12, 2020. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan
is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also
violations of the MSA and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from
the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.
Sincerely,
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12102 Rule variance.
(1) Upon the written request of an applicant or agency,
the department may grant a variance from an
administrative rule if the alternative proposed
ensures that the health, care, safety, protection,
supervision, and needed services of children are
maintained.
Six foster home records were reviewed. One out of six records
did not have an approved variance in the file when it was
needed. A variance should have been completed and approved
by or before 8/1/19 and it was not approved until 8/30/19.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by
another agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record
containing all of the following documents:
(g) A copy of the foster parent /agency agreement
signed by the foster parent and the borrowing agency.
Three borrowed bed homes were reviewed. One out of three
homes did not have the foster parent/agency agreement signed
by the foster parent on or before placement. The child was
placed in the home on 10/19/20 but documentation was not
signed until 10/28/20.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in
the agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(c) Conduct a thorough investigation including all
necessary collateral contacts.
Three special evaluations were reviewed. One out of two did not
conduct a thorough investigation. One of the allegations
4

mentioned in the report was not fully discussed. A case note
was completed but there were still questions as to what actually
happened during the incident and if there needed to be a
violation of rules.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of
the following information:
(a) The date the information was received.
Three special evaluations were reviewed. Two out of three
investigations did not have the report completed within 15 days
of the conclusion of the evaluation. One evaluation was
concluded on 7/9/20 and the report was completed on 7/29/20.
The other evaluation was concluded on 8/4/20 and the report
was completed on 8/28/20. Once the foster parents are
provided the verbal summary, usually accompanied by the
3080, the evaluation has been concluded. From this point on,
the writer and supervisor has 15 days to complete the report.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report
required by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar days
of its completion.
Three special evaluations were reviewed. One out of three did
not have verification that the foster parent received the special
evaluation within 10 days of writing the report.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(g) Information about the child was shared with the new
placement, consistent with the requirements of R
400.12417.
Eight foster care files were reviewed. One out of eight files did
not document preparation before placement of the child.
5

R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement
of a child:.
(b) Child’s date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child’s health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating
to the care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or replacement
of the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster parent
to provide a stable, safe, and healthy environment for the
foster child and the foster family, including information
about siblings who do not reside in the foster home.
(i) Name of assigned social service worker
Eight foster care files were reviewed. One out of eight files did
not have a DHHS 3307 in the file which documented these
above areas.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each
child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and
at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Eight foster care files were reviewed. Twenty service plans were
reviewed. One out of twenty service plans were not completed
within 120 calendar days. The report was due on 9/9/20 and
was completed on 9/22/20.
R 400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(b), shall include all of the following
information:
(c) A summary of information pertinent to the updated
services plan received since the last service plan from the
child, the child's parents or legal guardian, foster parents,
6

referring agency, and others, unless the agency documents
why any of these entities cannot be involved.
Eight foster care files were reviewed. One out of eight did not
have an update on the caregiver’s input.
R 400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(b), shall include all of the following
information:
(d) Assessment of progress in achieving the
permanency goal for the child.
Eight foster care files were reviewed. One out of eight files did
not assess progress in all areas, specifically in education.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional ISEPrequirements except for the following:
ISEP 6.16.3 - Page 23 Relative Foster Parents (Commitment 52).
(a) When placing a child with a relative who has not been previously licensed as a
foster parent, DHHS shall:
(3) within 30 days, complete a home study determining whether the relative should,
upon completion of training and submission of any other required
One out of eight foster care files did not have a home study competed within 30 days of
placement .Home study should have been completed on 7/19/20 but was completed on
8/3/20.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that there
are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in section
1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements
except for the following:
DHHS Policy FOM 722.03 page 14-16 Placement exception request (PER) – Was a
PER completed when required and completed quarterly.
7

Eight foster care files were reviewed. Two out eight files did not have PERS completed
when necessary. One PER is still in progress for a CCI placement. The three subsequent
PERS were not completed timely. Another file needed a PER for sibling splits. The sibling
split occurred on 6/10/20 and the PER was completed on 9/4/20.
DHHS Policy FOM 722-6H Page 5 CASEWORKER CONTACT WITH CHILD IN OUT-
OF-HOME PLACEMENT
Eight foster care files were reviewed. One out of eight files did not have two face to face
contacts within the first two months of placement.
DHHS Policy FOM 722-06H Page 3 QUALITY VISITS
Eight foster care files were reviewed. One out of eight did not have a quality case
contact, specifically related to documenting the CCI personnel conversation with the
caseworker.
DHHS Policy 722-06B page 1-7 Family Team Meeting
Eight foster care files were reviewed. Two out of eight foster care files did not
have an FTM for case service planning.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
Technical Assistance was provided for CAP follow up. Training documentation was
reviewed for Interim 2020 CAP. Agenda documents were provided to verify that
workers were given training in the areas specified in the CAPS. The agendas did not
document specifically what was trained only that “Licensing” was part of the agenda.
Any items outlined in the CAP will need to be documented appropriately so that
verification of the completion of the CAP can be concluded. For training outlined in
the CAP, it should be clearly documented who was in attendance and what topics
were discussed as well as the date of the training.
Technical Assistance was provided for R. 400.12327 (5) (b). Any reference to child
protective services is protected under 1975 PA 238, MCL 722.621 to 722.638. The
acronyms, MIC and CPS are not to be documented in licensing special evaluation
reports.
Technical Assistance was provided for R. 400.12327 (7). One of the files had a
corrective action plan, signed, and documented before the agency wrote the special
evaluation and before the foster parent received the final special evaluation report. It
was discussed wit the agency that the foster parent it to receive the report before a
signed CAP can be completed. The agency can discuss the CAP with the foster
8

parent before the report is actually written, but the foster parent has the right to see
the report and add their written response to be included to the report.
Technical Assistance was provided for R 400.12212: Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance within a probationary
period or not later than 6 months after the staff member assumes his or her current
responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a written evaluation shall be conducted each
year.
The human resource department has created performance evaluation documents that
dictate a “due date” for Oakland County DHHS. This due date is not necessarily the
actual date that the annual is due. If I were to use this “due date” the performance
evaluations would be in violation of their own policy. The agency will be not be using the
“due dates” as the date the performance evaluation is due but will ensure the current
performance evaluation is completed annually based on the previous year’s
performance evaluation date. The signature date accepted is the last dated signature.
V. Analyst Contacts
There are no safety concerns to document.
VI. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were two incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The agency conducted a special evaluation on both areas and accepted a CAP
if applicable.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
Interim 2020 Cap was completed.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
9

Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
